Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Education Workshop for Wisconsin Institutions of Higher Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging in hands-on field experience, laboratory/project-based entrepreneurship tasks and mentorship experiences.

The University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh aims to conduct an Environmental Education Workshop for Wisconsin Institutions of Higher Education to support the improvement of environmental education instruction for preservice students in the state's public and private teacher education programs. The objectives are to (1) develop a shared vision for what environmental education should be for all teacher preparation programs in Wisconsin; (2) produce 20 environmental education instructional activities for middle and high school preservice teachers that integrate traditionally separate disciplines; and 3) bring the strengths and expertise of faculty from different institutions together to collaboratively offer new learning opportunities about environmental education for students now and in the future. The project offers a 3-day, Environmental Education workshop to faculty from all 33 public and private teacher preparation programs in Wisconsin. Two individuals in different licensure program or content areas from each institution will be invited to participate (66 participants total).

The three- day workshop that will help determine a shared vision for how to include environmental education in teacher preparation programs (a legal requirement within the state) and produce deliverables (20 environmental education instructional activities) that may be used in programs for middle and high school preservice teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation funded professional development workshops focused on environmental education for faculty at institutions of higher education in Wisconsin. Teacher seeking licenses in agriculture, early childhood, middle childhood to early adolescent, science and social studies are required to receive environmental education including the conservation of natural resources during their teacher preparation programs by Wisconsin Administrative Code PI 34.15(4)(b). Although teacher preparation programs in Wisconsin must address environmental education and the conservation of natural resources, the impediments to doing so are well documented by Ashmann and Franzen (2015), Heimlich, et al (2004), McKeown-Ice (2000), and Powers (2004).

Two workshops in environmental education were conducted over a total of six days. Forty-two participants representing 19 public and private institutions of higher education participated in these workshops. Each institution was invited to send two participants. The goals for this workshop included the development of integrated instructional activities for use by faculty in their classes, proposals for collaborative efforts to offer new opportunities in environmental education to preservice students by multiple institutions and emphasizing the role that the existing Teacher Educators Network for Environmental Education can play in networking teacher preparation programs throughout the state. Participants were expected to implement one or more of the instructional activities from our workshop with preservice students on their campuses.

Our ultimate goal during the workshops was to provide the time and space for faculty to come together around improving environmental education at each institution with an explicit focus on developing instructional material for that institution, and the human and social resources essential for sustaining conversations about effective teaching and meaningful learning. The stated goals of the workshops were to:

  • develop a shared vision for what environmental education should be for all teacher preparation programs in Wisconsin;
  • produce 20 environmental education instructional activities for preservice teachers that integrate traditionally separate disciplines; and
  • bring the strengths and expertise of faculty from different institutions together to collaboratively offer new learning opportunities about environmental education for students now and in the future.

Outcomes from the workshops included producing and disseminating the on-line book cited below that contains 34 environmental education instructional activities designed for use with preservice teachers:

Franzen, R. L., Ashmann, S., Beeth, M. E., Russell, C. T., Rydberg, Z. & Schiebel, A. (2018). Environmental Education Activities for Teacher Educators: A Sampling from Wisconsin.

Dissemination of the professional development model for conducting workshops with faculty from higher education and analyses of the instructional activities produced by the participants were also presented at the three professional conferences cited below. Audiences for these conferences included K-12 teachers of science who could work with preservice teachers, science teacher educators at institutions of higher education, and the membership of an organization focused on formal and non-formal learning related to environmental education.

Beeth, M. E., Ashmann, S. & Franzen, R. L. (2019). Environmental Education Activities for Teacher Educators: A Sampling from Wisconsin. Presented at the 2019 National Science Teachers Association Conference, St. Louis, MO. April 11-14, 2019.

Beeth, M. E., Ashmann, S. & Franzen, R. L. (2019). Impacts and implications of a faculty professional development workshop in environmental education. Presentation at the 2019 International Conference of the Association for Science Teacher Education, Savannah, GA. January 3-5, 2019.

Ashmann, S., Franzen, R. L. & Beeth, M. E. (2018). Improving EE in teacher education: A statewide effort in Wisconsin. Presentation at the 47th Annual Conference of the North American Association for Environmental Education, Spokane, WA. October 11, 2018.

Participants from this National Science Foundation supported workshops were also invited by the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction to help write curriculum for the Wisconsin Standards for Environmental Literacy and Sustainability, released in 2018. Most participants remain engaged in issues related to teaching environmental education and connected through the Teacher Educators Network for Environmental Education.
